natural problem:
Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = (matrix([[|-1,2|],[|3,4|]]))"
and h1 : "A^6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$ The final Answer is (2223,4510)
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\ &= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
 &= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Then \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = (matrix([[|-1,2|],[|3,4|]]))"
and h1 : "A^6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a matrix A, defined as A = [[-1,2],[3,4]], find the real numbers p and q such that A^6 equals p times A plus q times the identity matrix. The final answer is (p, q) = (2223, 4510).

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix ([[ -1, 2], [3, 4]])"
and h1 : "I = matrix_identity 2"
and h2 : "A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$ The final Answer is (2223,4510)
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\ &= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
 &= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Then \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix ([[ -1, 2], [3, 4]])"
and h1 : "I = matrix_identity 2"
and h2 : "A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix A with the values -1, 2, 3, 4 in its rows and I as the 2x2 identity matrix, find the values of p and q such that the sixth power of the matrix A is equal to p times A plus q times I. The final answer is p=2223 and q=4510.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes A :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real

 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
defines "A \<equiv> matrix([[ -1, 2], [3, 4]])"
assumes h0 : "A powr 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R (mat 1)"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a matrix A, defined as A = [[-1, 2], [3, 4]], find the constants p and q such that A to the power of 6 equals to p times A plus q times the identity matrix. The final answer is (p, q) = (2223, 4510).

assumes h0 : "A = ((-1,2),(3,4))"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = (|-1, 2; 3, 4|)"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"

a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that

 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = (|-1, 2; 3, 4|)"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"

a_4.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix A with elements -1, 2, 3, and 4 arranged in order from the top left to the bottom right, and the identity matrix I, find the scalar values p and q such that the sixth power of A equals p times A plus q times I. The final answer is (p, q) = (2223, 4510).

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [[-1,2], [3,4]]"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "\<exists>p q. A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "fst (SOME (p, q). A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I) = 2223" 
and "snd (SOME (p, q). A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I) = 4510"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$ The final Answer is (2223,4510)
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\ &= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
 &= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Then \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [[-1,2], [3,4]]"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "\<exists>p q. A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "fst (SOME (p, q). A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I) = 2223" 
and "snd (SOME (p, q). A ^ 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I) = 4510"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider a 2x2 matrix $A=\begin{bmatrix}-1 & 2\\ 3 & 4\end{bmatrix}$ and the 2x2 identity matrix $I$. Find two real numbers $p$ and $q$ such that $A^6 = pA + qI$. The final answers are $p = 2223$ and $q = 4510$.

 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[ -1, 2], [3, 4]])"
and h1 : "I = matrix([[1,0],[0,1]])"
and h2 : "A^6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"

theorem

 *)

fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2" and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [ [-1, 2], [3, 4] ]"
and h1 : "I = matrix [ [1, 0], [0, 1] ]"
and h2 : "A^6 = p * A + q * I"
shows  "(p, q) = (2223, 4510)"

a_8.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix A with elements -1, 2, 3, 4 and an identity matrix I, find the constants p and q such that the sixth power of matrix A equals p times matrix A plus q times matrix I. The final answer is p = 2223 and q = 4510.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [ [-1, 2], [3, 4] ]"
and h1 : "I = matrix [ [1, 0], [0, 1] ]"
and h2 : "\<exists>p q. matrix_pow A 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "\<exists>p q. p = 2223 \<and> q = 4510"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$ The final Answer is (2223,4510)
 ### Proof
 Note that \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\ &= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
 &= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Then \begin{align} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
 &= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\ &= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}. \end{align}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and I :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [ [-1, 2], [3, 4] ]"
and h1 : "I = matrix [ [1, 0], [0, 1] ]"
and h2 : "\<exists>p q. matrix_pow A 6 = p *\<^sub>R A + q *\<^sub>R I"
shows  "\<exists>p q. p = 2223 \<and> q = 4510"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a matrix $A$ defined as $\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ and the identity matrix $I$ defined as $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, find two real numbers $p$ and $q$ such that $A^6 = pA + qI$. The final answer is $p = 2223$ and $q = 4510$.
